<description type="note">Preliminaries and editorial matter including introduction and glossary omitted.<lb/>The following plays have been taken from this source:<lb/>Source texts incomplete</description>
Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
XV. THE CHAUNDELERS. The Angels and the Shepherds. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor
[PERSONS OF THE PLAY. Primus, Pastor. Secundus, Pastor. Tertius, Pastor.]

[Scene, the fields near Bethlehem.] 1. i Past. Bredir in haste, takis heede and here What I wille speke and specifie, Sen we walke Ã¾us, withouten were, What mengis my moode nowe mevyd will I. Oure forme-fadres, faythfull in fere, Bothe Osye and Isaye, Preued Ã¾at a prins with-outen pere Shulde descende doune in a lady, And to make mankynde clerly, To leche Ã¾am Ã¾at are lorne. And in Bedlem here-by Sall Ã¾at same barne be borne. 2. ii. Past. Or he be borne in burgh hereby, Balaham, brothir, me haue herde say, A sterne shulde schyne and signifie, With lightfull lemes like any day. And als the texte it tellis clerly By witty lerned men of oure lay, With his blissed bloode he shulde vs by, He shulde take here al of a maye. I herde my syre saye, When he of hir was borne, She shulde be als clene maye As euer she was by-forne. 3. iii Past. A! mercifull maker, mekill is thy myght, That Ã¾us will to Ã¾i seruauntes see, Might we ones loke vppon Ã¾at light, Gladder bretheren myght no men be! I haue herde say, by Ã¾at same light The childre of Israell shulde be made free, The force of the feende to felle in sighte, And all his pouer excluded shulde be. Wherfore, brether, I rede Ã¾at wee Flitte faste ouere thees felles, To frayste to fynde oure fee, And talke of sumwhat ellis. [Vision of Angels in the sky. 4. i Pas. We! hudde! ii Pas. We! howe! i Pas. Herkyn to me! ii Pas. We! man, Ã¾ou maddes all out of myght. i Pas. We! colle! iii Pas. What care is comen to Ã¾e? i Pas. Steppe furth and stande by me right, And tell me Ã¾an Yf Ã¾ou sawe euere swilke a sight! iii Pas. I? nay, certis, nor neuere no man. 5. ii Pas. Say, felowes, what! fynde yhe any feest, Me falles for to haue parte, parde! i Pas. Whe! hudde! be-halde into the heste! A selcouthe sight Ã¾an sall Ã¾ou see vppon Ã¾e skye! ii Pas. We! telle me men, emang vs thre, Whatt garres yow stare Ã¾us sturdely? 6. iii Pas. Als lange as we haue herde-men bene, And kepis Ã¾is catell in Ã¾is cloghe, So selcouth a sight was neuere non sene. i Pas. We! no colle! nowe comes it newe i-nowe, Ã¾at mon we fynde. Itt menes some meruayle vs emang, Full hardely I you behete. 7. i Past. What it shulde mene Ã¾at wate not ?ee, For all Ã¾at ?e can gape and gone: [Angel sings. I can synge itt alls wele as hee, And on a-saie itt sall be sone proued or we passe. Yf ?e will helpe, halde on! late see, for Ã¾us it was. Et tunc cantant. 8. ii Pas. Ha! ha! Ã¾is was a mery note, Be the dede Ã¾at I sall dye, I haue so crakid in my throte, Ãat my lippis are nere drye. iii Pas. I trowe you royse, For what it was fayne witte walde I, That tille vs made Ã¾is noble noyse. 9. i Pas. An aungell brought vs tythandes newe, A babe in Bedlem shulde be borne, Of whom Ã¾an spake oure prophicie trewe, And bad us mete hym Ã¾are Ã¾is morne, Ã¾at mylde of mode. I walde giffe hym bothe hatte and horne, And I myght fynde Ã¾at frely foode. 10. iii Pas. Hym for to fynde has we no drede, I sall you telle a-chesonne why, ?one sterne to Ã¾at lorde sall vs lede. ii Pas. ?a! Ã¾ou sais soth, go we for-thy hym to honnour. And make myrthe and melody, with sange to seke oure savyour. Et tunc cantant. [Walking along, they come to Bethlehem. 11. i Pas. Breder, bees all blythe and glad, Here is the burght Ã¾er we shulde be. ii Pas. In Ã¾at same steede now are we stadde, Thare-fore I will go seke and see. Slike happe of heele neuere herde-men hadde; Loo! here is the house, and here is hee. iii Pas. ?a! for sothe Ã¾is is the same, [They enter. Loo! whare Ã¾at lorde is layde, Be-twyxe two bestis tame, Right als Ã¾e aungell saide. 12. i Pas. The Aungell saide Ã¾at he shulde saue This worlde and all Ã¾at wonnes Ã¾er-in, Therfore yf I shulde oght aftir crave, To wirshippe hym I will be-gynne. [They adore the child. Sen I am but a symple knave, Ãof all I come of curtayse kynne, Loo! here slyke harnays as I haue, A baren broche by a belle of tynne At youre bosom to be, And whenne ?e shall welde all, Gud sonne, for-gete no?t me, Yf any fordele falle. 13. ii Pas. Ãou sonne! Ã¾at shall saue boÃ¾e see and sande, Se to me sen I haue Ã¾e soght, I am ovir poure to make presande Als myn harte wolde, and I had ought. Two cobill notis vppon a bande, Loo! litill babe, what I haue broght, And when ?e sall be lorde in lande, Dose goode agayne, for-gete me noght. For I haue herde declared Of connyng clerkis and clene, That bountith aftir rewarde; Nowe watte ?e what I mene. 14. iii Pas. Nowe loke on me, my lorde dere, Ãof all I putte me noght in pres, Ye are a prince with-outen pere, I haue no presentte Ã¾at you may plees. But lo! an horne spone, Ã¾at haue I here, And it will herbar fourty pese, Ãis will I giffe you with gud chere, Slike novelte may noght disease. Fare [wele] Ã¾ou swete swayne, God graunte vs levyng lange, And go we hame agayne, And make mirthe as we gange.
